Foreign governments can purchase items through FMS, with the U.S. government negotiating packages on their behalf. FMF grants and loans are provided to selected foreign governments for FMS purchases. The State Department determines which nations receive military assistance. In FY2015, $5.9 billion was spent on FMF, with $4.4 billion going to Israel and Egypt. In FY2016, total estimated FMF in the enduring and OCO budgets was $6.0 billion, with $5.7 billion requested for FY2017. The SDAF supports the inventory of defense articles for partner nations and may also be used to purchase defense services. The International Military Education and Training (IMET) Program provides grants for foreign military and civilian defense personnel to attend U.S. professional military education institutions. It emphasizes longer training experiences in the United States to expose students to the American way of life. The program was expanded in 1990 to include opportunities for foreign civilian defense personnel to attend educational programs on responsible defense resource management. The IMET program in the United States aims to maximize student exposure to American life. FY2016 funding was $108.1 million, with a $110.3 million request for FY2017.
